data.title: NexPoint Real Estate Finance outlines $0.48–$0.53 Q4 earnings guidance amid robust portfolio growth and new capital deployment
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: NexPoint Real Estate Finance (NREF) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Paul Richards, EVP of Finance and CFO, reported net income of $1.12 per diluted share for Q3 2025, up from $0.74 per diluted share in Q3 2024, attributing the increase to higher unrealized gains on preferred stock and stock warrant investments. Earnings available for distribution were $0.51 per diluted share, and cash available for distribution was $0.53 per diluted share. Richards stated, "Book value per share increased 8% from Q2 2025 to $18.79 per diluted share, with the increase being primarily due to unrealized gain on our preferred stock investment and stock warrants."
  • Richards highlighted, "During the quarter, we funded $42.5 million on a life science preferred," and detailed the sale of a multifamily property for $60 million resulting in a $3.7 million gain, alongside raising $65.7 million from the Series B preferred stock offering.
  • Richards announced the launch of a $200 million Series C preferred offering at an 8% coupon, with the strategy to deploy capital "at 400 basis point plus spreads at the cost of this capital."
  • Richards provided Q4 guidance, stating, "We are guiding an earnings available for distribution and cash available for distribution as follows: earnings available for distribution of $0.48 per diluted share at a midpoint with a range of $0.43 on the low end and $0.53 on the high end. Cash available for distribution of $0.50 per diluted share at the midpoint with a range of $0.45 on the low end and $0.55 on the high end."
  • Matthew McGraner, EVP & Chief Investment Officer, shared that the Alewife project secured a long-term lease with Lila Sciences, describing it as a "flagship pioneering-backed AI and life science company." McGraner explained, "The Lila lease stabilizes the project and gives it a powerful base from which to drive leasing momentum and catalyze a new AI cluster at the broader Alewife project."

Outlook

  • Management guided Q4 2025 earnings available for distribution at $0.48 per diluted share (midpoint), ranging from $0.43 to $0.53, and cash available for distribution at $0.50 per diluted share (midpoint), ranging from $0.45 to $0.55.
  • Richards noted, "Given the heightened demand, we are now in the process of launching a Series C preferred, which will be a $200 million offering at an 8% coupon."
  • Management expressed cautious optimism for 2026, with McGraner stating, "On the whole, cautious optimism best fits our rental market outlook and believe 2026 will usher in a positive revenue for the first time in several years."

Financial Results

  • Net income for Q3 2025 was $1.12 per diluted share, driven by increased unrealized gains. Earnings available for distribution and cash available for distribution fell year-over-year but supported the declared $0.50 per share dividend, with coverage of 1.06x.
  • Book value per share rose 8% from the prior quarter to $18.79 per diluted share.
  • Portfolio comprised 88 investments with a total outstanding balance of $1.1 billion, allocated 47.3% to multifamily, 33.9% to life sciences, and 15.9% to single-family rentals.
  • The company raised $65.7 million in gross proceeds from the Series B preferred stock raise and is nearing the $400 million offering limit.
  • Debt outstanding was $720.9 million at a weighted average cost of 5.3% and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.93x. A new $45 million senior unsecured note was issued at a 7.875% coupon, replacing $36.5 million in previous notes.

Q&A

  • Jason Sabshon, KBW: Requested an updated view on the life science sector and NREF’s exposure. McGraner responded, "The good news about our life sciences book is we didn't start making life science loans until 2024...Where you do see weakness...is more or less in their...B assets in their noncore markets. Where they are showing strength...is in the gateway markets of San Diego, San Francisco and...Cambridge and Boston. And that's where our exposure is."
  • Sabshon asked about multifamily deployment preferences amid softness in bridge lending. McGraner replied, "Most of the softness in the bridge space was the floating rate bridge loans that were originated in '21, '22 with 2-, 3-year maturities that can't be refied out today...There is light at the end of the tunnel. It's not a question of if, it's just when...So there is a little bit of pressure, but I think it's workable."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised concerns about sector-specific risks, particularly in life sciences and multifamily deployment, with a neutral tone—questions focused on risk management and capital allocation without overt skepticism.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone during prepared remarks and Q&A, using phrases such as "very proud to see that the first of...kind of one of the first investments that we made in life science is bearing fruit for the company and the shareholders," and "reasons for Supreme optimism going forward."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remains confident with added emphasis on optimism for 2026, while analysts maintain a consistent, neutral tone.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management’s Q4 guidance for earnings available for distribution increased from a midpoint of $0.42 last quarter to $0.48 this quarter, indicating an improved outlook.
  • Book value per share saw a notable jump of 8% quarter-over-quarter, compared to a 1% increase last quarter.
  • The portfolio expanded from 86 to 88 investments, with increased life sciences exposure and continued focus on multifamily.
  • Management’s optimism regarding sector fundamentals and capital deployment has strengthened, with more explicit forward-looking statements about 2026 market dynamics.
  • Analysts’ focus shifted from credit trends in GSE B-Pieces and lease-up progress to sector risk and deployment strategy.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management identified challenges in bridge lending, particularly for floating rate loans originated in 2021 and 2022, but described the situation as manageable due to improving fundamentals.
  • The storage sector continues to be impacted by muted housing activity and limited new supply, but rising rates suggest a turnaround in 2026.
  • Life sciences exposure is concentrated in gateway markets, which management described as more resilient than noncore markets.
  • Management cited expensive land, high interest rates, and tight bank financing as ongoing headwinds to new development, but pointed to low leverage and a strong credit profile as risk mitigants.

Final Takeaway

Management highlighted robust quarterly results, a strengthened balance sheet, and a healthy capital position, with expectations for an improved sector outlook and new investment opportunities in 2026. The company emphasized its disciplined approach, focus on core markets, and readiness to deploy newly raised capital, while maintaining confidence in dividend coverage and continued portfolio growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Ex-consultants are being enlisted to train AI to do their old jobs
data.description:
The global consulting industry, already slowed by weaker markets in the U.K., China, Saudi Arabia and Australia, is now facing a new test from within: former consultants teaching artificial intelligence how to do their work.

Roughly 150 ex-consultants from McKinsey, Bain and Boston Consulting Group have been hired under a program called Project Argentum, Bloomberg News reported Thursday, citing documents from the program. The initiative is run by Mercor, an AI-driven hiring startup that previously helped staff a similar effort to train OpenAI’s models on investment banking tasks.

Argentum’s participants are helping AI systems, including Google’s (GOOG) (GOOGL) Gemini, learn to perform consulting fundamentals such as market analysis, financial modeling, and presentation writing. Applicants complete an AI-based interview, and successful hires are paid about $110 an hour for up to 19 hours weekly, the documents indicate.

The project highlights the consulting sector’s uneasy relationship with automation. As firms cut costs and client demand cools, many -- including McKinsey, which uses its internal platform “Lilli” for slide decks and proposals -- are integrating generative AI into daily operations.

While AI could help consultants handle routine work more efficiently, the same technology may eventually let clients bypass firms altogether for basic analytical tasks once handled by junior staff.

Mercor’s online job posting describes Argentum as a “long-term collaboration with a leading AI lab” aimed at enhancing model performance on consulting-related projects. Participants must follow strict guidelines to ensure professional-quality writing and data accuracy.

The effort underscores how quickly AI is moving beyond experimentation to absorb high-skill professional workflows, potentially redefining what entry-level consulting looks like in the years ahead, Bloomberg News reported.

data.title: CMS Energy outlines $25B+ capital pipeline and raises 2025 EPS guidance while advancing data center growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: CMS Energy Corporation (CMS) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Garrick Rochow, President, CEO & Director, reported a strong operational, regulatory, and financial quarter, stating, "I am very pleased with the results and continue to see us well positioned for the full year and in the long term." He highlighted constructive regulatory outcomes, including a final order in the renewable energy plan approving an additional 8 gigawatts of solar and 2.8 gigawatts of wind through 2035, which are set to be integrated into the next 5-year plan. Rochow emphasized the positive regulatory environment in Michigan and noted the company received a constructive order in the gas rate case, approving approximately 75% of the final ask and 95% of infrastructure investments. On the electric side, staff supported about 75% of the revised ask and 90% of the capital ask in the pending rate case.

  • The CEO described robust industrial growth, with approximately 450 megawatts connected year-to-date out of a planned 900 megawatts in the 5-year plan, and another approximately 100 megawatts of signed contracts. Rochow provided an outlook of "2% to 3% forecasted annual sales growth over the next 5 years" and referenced a growing pipeline, including a significant data center agreement poised to bring up to 1 gigawatt of load starting in early 2030. He stated, "I expect further progress, specifically contract signature as the large load tariff is finalized in November."

  • Rochow also highlighted customer affordability, cost management, and a $20 billion investment plan over the next 5 years, with over $25 billion of additional investment opportunities identified. He added, "Given our confidence in the year, we're raising the bottom end of this year's guidance range to $3.56 to $3.60 per share…and we are well positioned to be toward the high end of that range."

  • Rejji Hayes, Executive VP & CFO, stated, "For the third quarter, we delivered adjusted net income of $797 million or $2.66 per share, which compares favorably to the first 9 months of 2024, largely due to higher rate relief net of investment costs and favorable weather-related sales." Hayes noted increased year-to-date costs driven by higher vegetation management expense, and discretionary spending being used to advance gas system projects and electric reliability. He emphasized, "We have completed virtually all of our planned financings for 2025, the latest tranche of which was our settlement of approximately $500 million of forward equity contracts at share price levels favorable to our plan."

Outlook

  • Rochow announced the initiation of full-year 2026 guidance at $3.80 to $3.87 per share, reflecting 6% to 8% growth from the midpoint of the revised 2025 range. He confirmed the company is "well positioned to be toward the high end of that range."

  • The CEO reiterated that the Integrated Resource Plan filing is scheduled for mid-2026 and the updated capital and financial plan refresh will be provided on the Q4 call.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted net income for the first nine months of 2025 was $797 million, or $2.66 per share, up $0.19 versus the same period in 2024. The positive variance was attributed to constructive regulatory outcomes and favorable weather.

  • Hayes noted $0.37 per share of positive variance from weather and $0.28 per share from rate relief net of investment costs. Cost increases included $0.04 per share in vegetation management and $0.42 per share of negative variance from the outage at the Dearborn Industrial Generation facility and timing of select renewable projects. The company completed its 2025 financings and is exploring pull-ahead opportunities for 2026.

Q&A

  • Julien Dumoulin-Smith, Jefferies: Asked about timing and opportunity of the large load tariff and data center contracts. Rochow responded, "There are 3 large data centers in the final stages. That's up to 2 gigawatts of opportunity...I would expect that one at the bottom of the funnel...will move through that pipeline in short order after that tariff is in place."

  • Jeremy Tonet, JPMorgan: Inquired about how quickly $25 billion of CapEx could be integrated into the plan. Rochow replied, "You'll see more in electric reliability...We have approved renewable energy plan...that 5-year plan is going to be healthy with those type of investments."

  • Shahriar Pourreza, Wells Fargo: Asked about how much of the $25 billion would overlap before 2029. Rochow confirmed, "You'll see in our next 5-year plan, you're going to see some of that $25 billion move into the next 5 years."

  • Andrew Weisel, Scotiabank: Questioned IRP-related spending and capacity for new loads. Rochow said a portion would filter into the next 5-year plan and that the company has capacity for current connected load, with further expansion underway.

  • Travis Miller, Morningstar: Sought clarity on self-build versus PPA mix for renewables. Rochow said, "There's going to be a good portion of self-build in that mix. But remember, I'm not opposed to a PPA either because I really view that as a capital-light way of earnings."

  • Michael Sullivan, Wolfe Research: Queried on data center ramp timing and CapEx to equity sensitivity. Rochow indicated data center ramp starts late 2029/early 2030, and Hayes noted, "For every dollar of CapEx that's incremental to our plan, assume about $0.40 of common equity would need to be issued."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised multiple questions on timing and scale of capital investment, data center pipeline, and CapEx funding, reflecting a slightly positive to neutral tone focused on growth execution and risk management.

  • Management maintained a confident, occasionally cautious tone, with Rochow stating, "We are well equipped to serve and meet their needs as they advance," and Hayes emphasizing conservative planning and cost management. There was consistency in tone between prepared remarks and Q&A, with continued focus on execution and regulatory support.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone remains confident and constructive, with greater emphasis on converting pipeline opportunities and accelerating capital deployment.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter introduced finalized regulatory orders in both renewable and gas rate cases, and increased guidance for 2025 EPS.

  • Management shifted from highlighting a single data center agreement in Q2 to discussing three data centers at final stages and expanding the capital opportunity pipeline from $20 billion to $25 billion plus.

  • Analyst questions evolved from clarifying timelines and pipeline growth in Q2 to detailed inquiries on capital plan integration, IRP timing, and CapEx funding mechanisms.

  • The tone in both quarters is confident, but Q3 exhibits increased anticipation for accelerated growth and capital allocation as regulatory clarity improves.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted higher vegetation management costs and incremental spending on operational and customer initiatives.

  • The company addressed the potential for weather-related margin variability and storm activity, as well as the need to balance capital plans with affordability and efficient funding.

  • Hayes referenced contingency planning for weather and storm impacts and discussed regulatory asset treatment for the continued operation of the Campbell facility, ensuring Michigan customers are held harmless.

Final Takeaway

CMS Energy delivered a strong third quarter, supported by constructive regulatory decisions and robust economic growth in Michigan. Management raised the lower end of 2025 EPS guidance and initiated 2026 guidance with continued confidence toward the high end. With a growing pipeline of large data center and industrial projects, the company is positioned to accelerate over $25 billion of capital investment opportunities, while maintaining focus on affordability, reliability, and financial discipline to deliver long-term value for customers and investors.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Moderna gains on report it held talks with at least one large drugmaker (update)
data.description:
Update 12:30pm: Adds Moderna cancelling from a conference.

  • Moderna (MRNA) rose 12% after a report that it has held talks with at least one large drugmaker on a deal of "significant scope," according to a STAT News report. 
  • A takeover or a large partnership was on the table, according to the STAT News item on Thursday, which cited one person familiar with the discussions. The precise nature of the potential agreement was unclear. 
  • Moderna didn't immediately respond to Seeking Alpha's request for comment.
  • Separately on Thursday, Moderna (MRNA) cancelled from a UBS Global Healthcare conference scheduled for Nov. 9 - Nov. 12 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Moderna cancelled from the conference due to scheduling conflicts, according to an email viewed by Seeking Alpha.

data.title: Whitestone REIT reiterates 5% to 7% core FFO per share growth target as redevelopment initiatives progress
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Whitestone REIT (WSR) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO David Holeman highlighted that Whitestone achieved 94.2% occupancy for the quarter, up 30 basis points from Q2, describing this as “near record occupancy” and noting, “the fourth quarter is typically our strongest leasing quarter, we're set up for a very strong finish to the year.”
  • Holeman reported 4.8% same-store net operating income (NOI) growth, citing increases across shop space leases and tenant types in Texas and Arizona. He stated, “we extended and improved the terms of our credit facility, locking down one of the key variables for us to achieve our long-term 5% to 7% core FFO per share growth target.”
  • The company is nearing completion on redevelopment projects at La Mirada in Scottsdale, is in full swing at Lion Square in Houston, and has begun work at Terravita in Scottsdale. Holeman forecasted that redevelopment “will add up to 1% to Whitestone’s same-store NOI growth with a $20 million to $30 million capital spend over the next couple of years,” expecting the initiative to deliver in 2026.
  • Holeman disclosed “$0.26 in core FFO per share” for the quarter and an average base rent of $25.59, representing an 8.2% increase over the prior year’s third quarter.
  • The company disposed of Sugar Park Plaza in Houston, bringing total acquisitions and dispositions over the past three years to roughly $150 million, and anticipates “a couple more acquisitions very shortly and should have 1 to 2 dispositions to finish out the year.”
  • President & COO Christine C. Mastandrea reported signing $29.1 million in total lease value, with new lease spreads at 22.5% and renewals at 18.6%, for a combined 19.3% straight-line leasing spread. She noted, “Foot traffic across the portfolio was up 4% versus the third quarter of 2024.”
  • CFO J. Scott Hogan stated, “we reiterated our 2025 $1.03 to $1.07 core FFO per share guidance, improved our same-store NOI growth range to 3.5% to 4.5% and reiterated our long-term growth rates.” Hogan detailed a new amended and extended credit facility and explained, “We fixed an increased percentage of our overall debt, bringing the weighted average term on all of our debt to 4.3 years and the weighted average rate on our fixed debt to 4.8%.”

Outlook

  • Whitestone reiterated its 2025 core FFO per share guidance of $1.03 to $1.07 and improved its same-store NOI growth range to 3.5% to 4.5% for the year.
  • Management maintained its long-term 5% to 7% core FFO per share growth target and forecasted redevelopment projects to add up to 1% to same-store NOI growth, with completion expected in 2026.
  • The company expects continued strong leasing demand and no weakening in leasing spreads for the coming year, per both CEO Holeman and President Mastandrea.

Financial Results

  • Whitestone reported $0.26 in core FFO per share for the quarter.
  • Revenue for the quarter increased 6%, with improvement in uncollectible accounts contributing to a downward revision in full-year bad debt guidance.
  • Operating headcount is down 6% year-over-year; G&A cost reductions continue as the company scales.
  • Credit facility size was increased, with the aim to further reduce debt leverage in the coming quarters and years. Hogan noted approximately $800,000 in debt extinguishment costs related to refinancing, adjusted in core FFO.

Q&A

  • Jody, JMP Securities, asked about future leasing spreads as high-rent leases expire in 2026. CEO Holeman responded, “we continue to see really strong leasing demand, and there's no sign of any weakening in our leasing spreads.” President Mastandrea added, “We expect that we're going to continue to see the same rate of leasing spreads, if not more.”
  • Jody inquired about occupancy changes. Holeman explained, “we're taking some space back...for higher revenue and stronger quality tenants,” and CFO Hogan clarified, “Whitestone's 94.2% is tenants are in the space...up 30 basis points just over the second quarter.”
  • Jody requested an update on the Pillarstone JV. Holeman answered, “we have reached a settlement with the court. The court has to approve that settlement. And if it is done, then the proceeds are expected to be distributed by -- in December.”
  • Gaurav Mehta, Alliance Global Partners, asked about leverage targets. CFO Hogan stated, “we do expect the fourth quarter to be in the mid to high 6% range on debt-to-EBITDAre.”
  • Craig Kucera, Lucid Capital Markets, questioned real estate tax accruals, with Hogan attributing the increase mainly to Texas valuation processes and ongoing litigation, stating, “we do pass through most of those costs to our tenants, but we work very hard to keep those low.”
  • Bill Chen, Rhizome Partners, inquired about Pillarstone JV proceeds. Holeman shared that an additional $40 million could be distributed in December if court approval is received. Hogan confirmed leverage guidance “does not include the impact of any gains or losses or the Pillarstone proceeds.”
  • John Massocca, B. Riley Securities, asked about the pipeline of leases set to commence. Holeman explained the business model emphasizes quick commencement, resulting in minimal "signed not open" pipeline.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on future leasing spreads, occupancy trends, and leverage, with a generally positive but probing tone. Questions about the sustainability of leasing spreads, occupancy strategy, and Pillarstone JV reflected interest in durability and growth drivers.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing consistency in strategy and performance, with repeated assurances about strong leasing demand and future growth. Quotes such as “we have reached a settlement with the court” and “there's no sign of any weakening in our leasing spreads” reflect this confidence.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst sentiment remains constructive, with increased attention to JV proceeds and leverage impacts. Management’s tone has shifted to slightly higher confidence, particularly regarding redevelopment and credit facility achievements.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for core FFO per share and long-term growth targets remain unchanged, but the same-store NOI growth range was raised by 50 basis points on the lower end.
  • The company reported improved occupancy quarter-over-quarter and highlighted continued progress on redevelopment initiatives.
  • Analysts' questions in both quarters centered on leasing spreads, occupancy, and capital recycling, but Q3 included additional focus on JV settlements and leverage impact from one-time proceeds.
  • Management’s confidence and reiteration of targets remained consistent, with a more detailed update on credit facilities and a pronounced focus on upcoming redevelopment benefits in the current call.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management addressed potential risks related to real estate tax accruals in Texas, noting ongoing litigation and efforts to minimize tenant burden.
  • There is ongoing uncertainty about the timing and final approval of Pillarstone JV settlement proceeds, with management indicating that court approval is still pending.
  • Analyst concerns also touched on lease expirations and the impact of small space repositioning on occupancy, with management emphasizing proactive tenant upgrades for higher revenue.

Final Takeaway

Whitestone REIT’s management emphasized consistency in executing its strategy, highlighting a near-record occupancy rate, strong leasing spreads, and robust redevelopment progress. The company reiterated guidance for 2025 and long-term core FFO per share growth targets, with additional upside projected from ongoing redevelopment initiatives. Management remains confident in Whitestone’s ability to deliver on its targets, supported by a strengthened balance sheet, disciplined capital recycling, and continued strong leasing demand across its Texas and Arizona portfolios.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
